meanings.def: to slide a short distance by accident so that you fall or nearly fall
examples: She slipped and landed flat on her back.
As I ran up the stairs, my foot slipped and I fell.
She got on her feet and ran towards the door, slipping and sliding.
slip on something He slipped on a bar of soap in the shower room.
slip over She slipped over on the ice and broke her leg.

meanings.def: to slide out of position or out of your hand
examples: My hand slipped as I was slicing the bread and I cut myself.
+ adv./prep. His hat had slipped over one eye.
The fish slipped out of my hand.
The child slipped from his grasp and ran off.
(figurative) She was careful not to let her control slip.

meanings.def: to go somewhere quickly and quietly, especially without being noticed
examples: She slipped out of the house before the others were awake.
I slipped away before the end of the performance.
The ship slipped into the harbour at night.
A guard was posted at the door, in case anyone tried to slip in.
(figurative) She knew that time was slipping away.

meanings.def: to put something somewhere quickly, quietly or secretly
examples: slip something + adv./prep. Anna slipped her hand into his.
He slipped the letter back into its envelope.
He beat three defenders before slipping the ball past the goalkeeper.
She slipped her head around the door.
I managed to slip a few jokes into my speech.
I managed to slip in a few jokes.
I slipped the ring onto my finger.
slip something to somebody They'd slipped some money to the guards.
slip somebody something They'd slipped the guards some money.

meanings.def: to fall to a lower level; to become worse
examples: Standards have slipped in the last few years.
His popularity has slipped recently.
The director never lets the tension slip.
That's three times she's beaten me—I must be slipping!
A defeat would see them slip down the rankings.
At that time the Conservatives were slipping in the polls.
slip from something to something Pre-tax profits slipped from $3.9 million to $3.7 million,.

meanings.def: to pass into a particular state or situation, especially a difficult or unpleasant one
examples: He began to slip into debt.
The patient had slipped into a coma.
We seem to have slipped behind schedule.

meanings.def: to put clothes on or to take them off quickly and easily
examples: + adv./prep. to slip into/out of a dress
slip something + adv./prep. to slip your shoes on/off
He slipped a coat over his sweatshirt.

meanings.def: to get free; to make something/somebody/yourself free from something
examples: slip something The ship had slipped its moorings in the night.
The dog slipped its collar.
slip (something) + adj. The animal had slipped free and escaped.

meanings.def: to give somebody information that is supposed to be secret
examples: I happened to let it slip that he had given me £1 000 for the car.
She tried not to let slip what she knew.

meanings.def: to miss or fail to use an opportunity
examples: Don't let the chance to work abroad slip through your fingers.

meanings.def: (to become) out of control
examples: She said nothing in case her temper slipped out of gear.

meanings.def: to be easy to say or pronounce
examples: It's not a name that exactly trips off the tongue, is it?

meanings.def: if something slips your mind, you forget it or forget to do it
examples: I’m sorry I didn’t tell you. It completely slipped my mind.

meanings.def: to be easy to say or pronounce
examples: It's not a name that exactly slips off the tongue, is it?

meanings.def: to trick somebody
when somebody/something slips through the net, an organization or a system fails to find them and deal with them
examples: We tried to contact all former students, but one or two slipped through the net.

meanings.def: a small mistake, usually made by being careless or not paying attention
examples: He recited the whole poem without making a single slip.
There were a few slips in the translation.
It’s a common mistake among learners of English.
spelling mistakes
There are too many errors in your work.
The article is full of inaccuracies.
The report is full of howlers.
His team cannot afford any slips.
She made a couple of unfortunate slips during the talk.

meanings.def: a small piece of paper, especially one for writing on or with something printed on it
examples: I wrote it down on a slip of paper.
a betting slip
He got over fifty rejection slips before his novel was published.
His father signed a permission slip for a school field trip.
Please detach and return the slip below.
The Senator returns the blue slip with an indication whether they support or oppose the nominee.
a bank deposit slip
Please fill in the tear-off slip and return it the office.

meanings.def: an act of slipping
examples: One slip and you could fall to your death.

meanings.def: a piece of underwear like a thin dress or skirt, worn under a dress
a player who stands behind and to one side of the batsman and tries to catch the ball; the position on the field where this player stands
examples: fielding in the slips

meanings.def: to get away from somebody who is following or running after you
examples: I managed to give him the slip by hiding behind a wall.

meanings.def: a small or thin, usually young, person
examples: I was only a slip of a thing at the time.

meanings.def: a small mistake in something that you write or say
examples: Did I call you Richard? Sorry, Robert, just a slip of the tongue.
I didn't mean to say that—it was just a slip of the tongue.

meanings.def: nothing is completely certain until it really happens because things can easily go wrong
